Ok, going to try to be detailed as possible. Playing around in grub4dos with the newest grub4dos 12-29-11 and I wanted to see how many variables I could make...here is an example of one and the one I am having the most problem with and I will point out the issue with bold text Half working, if I echo %Answer10% I get the echo yes iftitle \[find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag \&\& call set DVDroot=%@root\^%\] Plop Boot Manager From(Try First)%DVDRoot%nBoot Computers With No USB Support. Will Not Work With USB Keyboards Or Mice password --md5 $1$A$hzYlFap3SLNNQ/tA7c3.S. find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag if exist %DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin set Answer10=yes clear if /i "%Answer10%"=="yes" set Plain=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin **\&\& set DIR=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin** if "%Answer10%"=="" echo Can Not Find PLop. Please Contact Superman! \&\& pause --wait=10 Going Back To Main Menu...Hit Enter At AnyTime \&\& configfile %DVDRoot%/menu.lst clear echo Loading PLoP From **%DIR%** pause --wait=10 Making Sure Paths Exist...Hit Enter Key At AnyTime kernel **%Plain%**
The above command is a stretch I know but whats going is the \&\& set DIR=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin will not work here and I use the pause command to see if the %DIR% was actually set and I get when running the command Loading PLoP From (blank) but the kicker is I can use the same command for something else in the menu.lst and it works Same command but different menu item and works: iftitle \[find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag \&\& call set DVDRoot=%@root\^%\] Partition Wizard 7.0 From %DVDRoot%nGreat Partitioning Tool password --md5 $1$A$hzYlFap3SLNNQ/tA7c3.S. find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag if exist %DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO set Answer1=yes clear if /i "%Answer1%"=="yes" set Wizard=%DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO **\&\& set DIR=%DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO** if "%Answer1%"=="" echo Can Not Find Partition Wizard. Please Contact Superman! \&\& pause --wait=10 Going Back To Main Menu...Hit Enter At AnyTime \&\& configfile %DVDRoot%/menu.lst clear echo Loading Partition Wizard From **%DIR%** pause --wait=10 Making Sure Paths Exist...Hit Enter Key At AnyTime map %Wizard% (hd32) \|\| map --mem %Wizard% (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader (hd32) ##(hd32) the only difference I can see is one is Answer1 and PLoP used Answer10. I know the DIR for PLoP is right because I can do this and PLoP boots iftitle \[find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag \&\& call set DVDroot=%@root\^%\] Plop Boot Manager From(Try First)%DVDRoot%nBoot Computers With No USB Support. Will Not Work With USB Keyboards Or Mice password --md5 $1$A$hzYlFap3SLNNQ/tA7c3.S. find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag **set Plain=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin** **set DIR=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin** clear echo Loading PLoP From **%DIR%** pause --wait=10 Making Sure Paths Exist...Hit Enter Key At AnyTime kernel **%Plain%**
The only thing I removed was **if exist %DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin set Answer10=yes clear if /i "%Answer10%"=="yes" set Plain=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin \&\& set DIR=%DVDRoot%/plpbt.bin if "%Answer10%"=="" echo Can Not Find PLop. Please Contact Superman! \&\& pause --wait=10 Going Back To Main Menu...Hit Enter At** This set Answer... if Answer... thing seems kinda buggy. I have changed the set Answer for PLoP to a hundred different thingswith the same results. I am not sure if this is because my menu is so big but its random that I can't set a directory or path with a if exist set Whatever=yes if /i "Whatever"=="yes" set whatever \&\& whatever This is the entire menu ``` ## 01.Partition Wizard 7.0 Home Edition iftitle [find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag && call set DVDRoot=%@root^%] Partition Wizard 7.0 From %DVDRoot%nGreat Partitioning Tool password --md5 $1$A$hzYlFap3SLNNQ/tA7c3.S. find --set-root --devices=c /laddsbootdvd.tag if exist %DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO set Answer1=yes clear if /i "%Answer1%"=="yes" set Wizard=%DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO && set DIR=%DVDRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO if "%Answer1%"=="" echo Can Not Find Partition Wizard. Weird how just ramdom the command will set the DIR and with curtin ones and then other times it will set the DIR for the ones it wouldn't before and new ones that was working before do not. Its not super important as I don't use a menu like this, just playing around to see how big I could make one. Wonder if the size would cause the randomness. Not trying to acomplish anything major...just OCD and can't wrap my head around why the command to set config paths or chainloader paths and DIR seem to be so random? The paths are 100% right and I know that's not the issue...but maybe the menu is too big? None of the ones for PLoP in bold above are working at the moment but few boots later, they will. Going to try the menu without the auto numbering ``` write 0x8274 0x2001 ```

forumNotes.content:
I tried this by changing the --devices=c to --devices=h and it seems to work OK. (I had to remove the password line)  
Are you testing this under an emulator or a real system?  
Can you reduce the menu to it's simplest case that will show the error (reduce number of menu items by deleting some)?  
If you do a fresh boot and choose the bad Plop menu straight away, does it fail - or must you use another menu item first?

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: P.S. Did you see the hotkey grub4dos utility is also available now which allows the user to use F1,F2, etc. to run a menu entry - see [http://www.rmprepusb...c-grub4dos-menu](http://www.rmprepusb.com/tutorials/57---automatic-grub4dos-menu "External link") - you need the **new** latest chenall grldr.

forumNotes.content:
> I tried this by changing the --devices=c to --devices=h and it seems to work OK. (I had to remove the password line The --devices=c is for my BootDVD because I don't use PLoP from my USB (Figured if I could boot to my USB, didn't need PLoP) But today I will add the PLoP to my USB and test the same lines but with --devices=h
> Are you testing this under an emulator or a real system? I always check my menu.lst through VB before I copy the menu.lst to my USB..all menu items are working in VB except the random PLoP not working but if I just use set=%DVDRoot%/PLoP/plpbt.bin, and remove the if exist and set Answer=, all works fine. I have also test on live machine from DVD with the same errors as described. I also remove the auto numbering from my menu but didn't fix anything so I added it back.
> Can you reduce the menu to it's simplest case that will show the error (reduce number of menu items by deleting some)? Yes I have done just the PLoP alone in VB with same result...random working. I can again just use set=%DVDRoot%/PLoP/plpbt.bin and all is well also if I add multiple set with if "Answer"=="yes" set whatever=whatever \&\& set whatever=whatever \&\& set whatever=whatever only the first will work if its working at all. I have also tried if exist Answer10 set=%DVDRoot%/PLoP/plpbt.bin..works but random again. I am using PLoP as an example but this really does this with any menu.lst entry random and it seems around the 10th menu entry. I am having issues with the 10th and 11th menu entry of my USB stick menu.lst also...The %Answer% variable always echos yes so Ii know that part is working. Should I not be using **find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag \&\& call set USBRoot=%@root\^%** for every menu entry? # Tilte 10 iftitle \[find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag \&\& call set DVDRoot=%@root\^%\] XP Complete %DVDRoot%n!Use Partition Wizard! find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag if exist %USBRoot%/Menu/xp.lst set Answer10=yes clear #set Menu1=%XPMenu%/Menu/xp.lst if /i "%Answer10%"=="yes" **set Config1=%USBRoot%/Menu/xp.l** st echo Loading XP Menu From **%Config1%** pause --wait=10 Checking For Path Error...Hit Enter At Anytime configfile **%Config1%** title root #Title 11 iftitle \[find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag \&\& call set USBRoot=%@root\^%\] Windows Vista-7-8 Complete % USBRoot%n find --set-root --devices=h /Menu if exist %USBRoot%/Menu/vista7.lst set Answer11=yes #set Answer11=yes clear if "%%Answer11%%"=="" echo Can Not Find vista7.lst. Please Contact Superman! if /i "%Answer11%"=="yes" **set Win7=%USBRoot%/Menu/vista7.lst** echo Loading NT6x Menu From **%Win7%** pause --wait=10 Checking For Path Error...Hit Enter At Anytime configfile **%Win7%** this will not echo or set %Menu1% or %Win7% but if I rem **if exist --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag set Answer11=yes** and **set Win7=%Menu2%/Menu/vista7.lst** and just use **set Win7=%Menu2%/Menu/vista7.lst** all is well My USB menu is not as big as my DVD menu. My goal today is to add the PLoP stuff to my USB and test and to use command prompt to type each line manually and echo to see if that works from 'c'. Would any of my set=Answer stuff interfere with grud4dos coding? Wouldn't think so
> P.S. Did you see the hotkey grub4dos utility is also available now which allows the user to use F1,F2, etc. to run a menu entry Yes but if I have bootmgr on the root of my USB and the below command boots the bootmgr from my USB and not hard drive
``` iftitle [find --set-root --devices=h /bootmgr] ^F2 Press F2 to Boot Windows from hard disk [/color] [color="#0000ff"]find --set-root --devices=h /bootmgr [/color] [color="#0000ff"]chainloader /bootmgr ```




``` title ^F1 Press F1 to Boot From (hd0,0)[/color][/color] [color="#0000ff"][color="#0000ff"]chainloader (hd0,0)+1 ```

9 times out of 9 my USB drive is (hd0,0), how would the above command boot the hard drive if it's say (hd1,0) because the USB is labeled (hd0,0)
I think some check ranges should be added, like this
``` title Press F1 to boot from Hard Drive checkrange 0x80 read 0x8280 && map () (hd1) checkrange 0x80 read 0x8280 && map (hd1) () checkrange 0x80 read 0x8280 && map --hook rootnoverify (hd0,0) chainloader +1 || chainloader /ntldr ```

forumNotes.content:
OK, now you have pasted the actual menu that you used, the answer is simple! You have extra spaces at the end of the line!
find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag if exist %USBRoot%/PLoP/plpbt.bin set Answer=Yes\*\* clear If you simply delete the spaces it will work! You have set Answer to Yes\\ !!! tip: Whenever you echo a variable to see what it is, use \*%Answer%\* so you can see any spaces.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
You only need to set USBRoot once in the first menu (it will then be set overall). Why not use the iftitle fully so the options are only listed if they are on the USB drive?? e.g.

``` ## 01.Partition Wizard 7.0 Home Edition iftitle [find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag && call set USBRoot=%@root^% && if exist %USBRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO] Partition Wizard 7.0 From %USBRoot%nGreat Partitioning Tool find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag set Wizard=%USBRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO password a map %Wizard% (hd32) || map --mem %Wizard% (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader (hd32) title root ## 02.Image For Linux 2.66 iftitle [find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag && if exist %USBRoot%/IMAGES/IFL.ISO] Image for Linux 2.66 From %USBRoot%nBackup...Restore...Ghosting Tool find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag set IFL=%USBRoot%/IMAGES/IFL.ISO password a map %IFL% (hd32) || map --mem %IFL% (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader (hd32) ```

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
or just simplify it to:
``` iftitle [find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag && if exist /IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO] Partition Wizard 7.0\nGreat Partitioning Tool set Wizard=/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO find --set-root --devices=h %Wizard% password a map %Wizard% (hd32) || map --mem %Wizard% (hd32) map --hook root (hd32) chainloader (hd32) ```

> You only need to set USBRoot once in the first menu (it will then be set overall). > Why not use the iftitle fully so the options are only listed if they are on the USB drive?? e.g. I like that idea.
**iftitle \[*find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag* \&\& call set USBRoot=%@root\^% \&\& if exist %USBRoot%/IMAGES/PWHE7.ISO\] Partition Wizard 7.0 From %USBRoot%nGreat Partitioning Tool *find --set-root --devices=h /laddsbootusb.tag*** but isn't the root set twice in your e.g? Also just remember and I'm sure you knew this but if you put the cursor over the line on whatever line or command and double click the line, it will then highlight and show the if the invisible script killer is there or not...e.g **Answer=Yes** just hover the cursor over the Answer=Yes, double click and the line will highlight and if the invisible script killer is there, it will highlight also

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
You must always use --set-root in the body of the menu if you are using various --set-root commands in iftitle lines because it could be changed by any one of the iftitle menu lines (if the last iftitle menu sets the root to the CD, then the current root drive will be the CD and not the USB drive).  
Don't know anything about grub24dos!
